urn:contentItem:5R2V-TWH1-F0J6-J1CG-00000-00Lightning strikes keep forest firefighters busy as fire season begins2017-12-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisLightning strikes keep forest firefighters busy as fire season begins

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews have battled 91 fires across the state since last Wednesday in a busy start to the fire season.

Of the 91 fires on public land, two were in the Murray Goldfields region.

FFMV senior fire management officer Jeff Wilkie said a lightning strike started a fire in Joseph Young Drive, Mount Alexander, last Friday.

"The Helitac out of Bendigo extinguished that fire pretty quickly. The storm went across at 5.45pm and the strike happened at 6.20pm," Mr Wilkie said.

Another fire was deliberately lit in Long Gully Creek, North Bendigo, last Saturday.

"That fire is under investigation. We were contacted by the fire tower at 2.35pm and assisted the CFA in controlling it," Mr Wilkie said.

In preparation for the fire season, FFMV crews have also been undertaking planned burns across the state with nine planned burns across 766 hectares in the Murray Goldfields region.

"It has been a busy start to the fire season, with lightning starting a significant number of fires," FFMV chief fire officer Stephanie Rotarangi said.

urn:contentItem:5M79-KMG1-JD34-V2NJ-00000-00Project firefighters learn skills2016-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisProject firefighters learn skillsChris Young

WHEN it comes to bushfires, prevention will always be better than the cure.

But knowing that fires can be unpredictable to say the least, Forest Fire Management Victoria decided it would be best to cover all bases.

Twenty-two new firefighters are undertaking a training course in Beechworth this week, covering a range of topics including fire behaviour, fire suppression, planned burning, safety and survival techniques.

Jarrod Hayse, from the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning said training was all about making sure they were prepared for what might lie ahead this summer.

"Our focus in the spring and leading into summer is all about preparedness," he said.

"This is the second course we've run in the Hume."

urn:contentItem:5PTH-4XH1-F0J6-J2M8-00000-00Planned burn program begins2017-10-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisPlanned burn program begins

Planned burns will begin in parts of central Victoria on Tuesday, weather permitting.

The first burn will take place in Gunbower State Forest at Rifle Butts Track, about five kilometres north of Cohuna.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting Murray Goldfields district manager, Adrian Parker, said the 15-hectare burn was in a priority area for risk reduction.

He said it would provide protection against bushfires coming from the north-west.

A 14-hectare burn will also take place in Waanyarra Natural Conservation Reserve, near Tarnagulla.

"These burns aim to reduce the speed and intensity of future bushfires," Adrian Parker.

"This is important work because smaller and less intense fires have less chance of growing to a size that will cause damage to communities and property."

FFM Victoria firefighters will continue to patrol the burn sites in the days following the burns.

People who experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.

To keep up to date on burns planned for the next 10 days, visit www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburns.

urn:contentItem:5N06-RRK1-F0J6-J1JR-00000-00Waiting for rain to start planned burns2017-03-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Waiting for rain to start planned burnsNatalie Croxon

THE autumn planned burning program has already begun in parts of the state, but it will not start in this region until more rain arrives.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Murray Goldfields district manager Paul Bates said the region needed about 40 to 50 millimetres of rain to bring fuel moisture content up to desirable levels for planned burning, which he believed would take another three to four weeks.

But preparation work is already under way.

Site scheduled for planned burns include Eaglehawk and Long Gully, Castlemaine, Wedderburn, Kamarooka and Maryborough.

Mr Bates said mid-autumn's stable weather generally meant good conditions for planned burns.

The burns will be conducted with the CFA.

For more information on when and where burns will be held, visit the planned burns website or call 1800 226 226.

A fuel reduction burn is underway near Wedderburn.

Authorities expect it will be complete by 8pm on Sunday.

They have warned that smoke might be visible from St Arnaud, Dunolly and Bealiba and provided the following advice:

urn:contentItem:5PNY-J7X1-F0JP-W4WS-00000-00CALIFORNIA BUSHFIRES KILL 102017-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19CALIFORNIA BUSHFIRES KILL 10

AT least 10 people are dead after more than a dozen bushfires whipped by powerful winds swept through northern California's wine country.

Authorities said the blazes, driven by winds of up to 80kmh, destroyed 1500 homes and businesses, sending thousands fleeing.

As he dashed through the ember-strewn streets of his neighbourhood in the city of Santa Rosa, Jeff Okrepkie knew it was probably the last time he would see his home.

His worst fears were confirmed yesterday, when a friend sent him a photo of what was left: a smouldering heap of burnt metal and debris.

"We live in the valley, where it's concrete and strip malls and hotels and supermarkets," Mr Okrepkie said. "The last thing you think is a forest fire is going to come and wipe us out." Marian Williams could feel the heat of a fire in Sonoma through the car as she fled. "Trees were on fire like torches," she said.Fourteen fires are burning north of San Francisco, and Governor Jerry Brown has declared a state of emergency in three counties full of vineyards.

urn:contentItem:5MXP-YB21-F0J6-J0RT-00000-00Helibase at Ovens gets major upgrade2017-02-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Helibase at Ovens gets major upgradeBRITTANY LYONS

A $230,000 upgrade to Forest Fire Management Victoria's Ovens helibase will enable it to manage up to 10 water-bombing aircraft and support crews.

The upgrade includes two new concrete helipads and an all-weather access road, according to FFM Victoria District Manager Jarrod Hayse.

"The ability to cater for helicopters and their support crews during emergency events is a significant benefit to the communities in the Alpine region," Mr Hayse said. The base had been crucial during emergency situations including October 2016 floods and annual bushfire season.

"Two helicopters are permanently based at Ovens during the bushfire season for rappel firefighting, water bombing and aerial observation," he said.

"Another huge benefit is the new portable fuel tanks, which means refuelling no longer involves the manual handling of fuel drums."

  A forest fire threatening a home in central Victoria has been brought under control.
   Twenty Country Fire Authority crews and a helicopter water bomber began fighting the slow-moving, five-hectare fire at Benloch, near Lancefield, just after 1pm on Monday.
   A CFA spokesperson said the fire was controlled just before 5pm.

urn:contentItem:57FP-65T1-JC0X-K01Y-00000-00ACT:Fire fighters mop up bushfire in ACT2013-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSACT:Fire fighters mop up bushfire in ACTCANBERRA Jan 8

  Firefighters are continuing to mop up a forest fire burning in the ACT's south.
   The fire is burning close to Mount Ginini in the western region of Namadgi National Park and is under control.


   The ACT Rural Fire Service has four units on the scene to fight the 26-hectare forest fire.
   Meanwhile, a helicopter reconnaissance flight will monitor whether there is any fire still burning at Sentry Box and Rendezvous Creek within Namadgi National Park.
   A cluster of small fires at Rendezvous Creek was extinguished after the site was water bombed on Monday.
   The chopper will use infrared detection equipment to pick up the presence of any hot spots in the areas.
   The bushfires were sparked by lightning when a storm hit the capital on Saturday evening.
   The alert and warning level for the three fires has been set at 'advice'.
   A total fire ban has been declared for Tuesday in the ACT, with fire danger rated at extreme due to forecast very hot and windy weather.

urn:contentItem:5N7W-XPG1-JD3N-54P6-00000-00Holiday makers shrug off the haze2017-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Holiday makers shrug off the hazeBETHANY TYLER

PLANNED burns are continuing in the Otways with a fleet of aircraft, bulldozers, fire vehicles and more than 60 firefighters involved in a multi-day operation at Big Hill.

The 380ha hazard reduction burn between Lorne and Eastern View is one of the most complex Forest Fire Management Victoria has done in the Otway district.

FFMV aerial drip torch operator Simon White, who was up in one of the aircraft yesterday, said it was rewarding to see an operation of such scale executed successfully. "Aircraft have played a critical role in monitoring the ... spread of this planned burn, conducting aerial ignition and also supporting crews on the ground," he said.

Despite the smoky skies above, families made the most of the school holidays at beaches and lookouts along the Great Ocean Road.Firefighters yesterday reminded people to register their private burn-offs to reduce the amount call-outs for false alarms.

urn:contentItem:5MB3-C6M1-F0JP-W4KN-00000-00Firewood season finishes2016-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Firewood season finishes

Firewood collection season has now ended.

Forest Fire Management Victoria forest and fire operations regional manager Peter Kambouris said it would be illegal for people to collect firewood on public land until the start of the designated autumn season.

Department staff would be patrolling parks, forests and reserves to make sure people were doing the right thing, he said.

Mr Kambouris said on-the-spot fines were $622, and those people with offences that go to court could be liable for up to $7773, a year in jail or both.

"The public will be able to start collecting firewood again from designated firewood collection areas from 1 March, 2017, pending suitable conditions." Mr Kambouris said.For more details, go online to delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood or 136186

urn:contentItem:5M8K-DY11-JD34-V3CK-00000-00Firewood collection season ending2016-11-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSFirewood collection season ending

The spring firewood collection season will close around Ballarat and across the state on Wednesday.

It will be illegal to collect firewood on public land after the closing date until March 1, provided conditions are suitable.

Forest Fire Management Victoria regional manager Peter Kambouris said there were a range of reasons for not allowing firewood collection in summer.

"It's both for safety, access and ecological reasons; in the summer there is the risk of fire from a range of factors, including from chainsaws," he said.

The break in seasons also gives flora and fauna a reprieve, with summer being a key breeding season.

Firewood must be collected from designated firewood collection areas and can only be for personal use. For more information visit:

For more, go to delwp.vic.gov.au/firewood

urn:contentItem:5PFX-77F1-JC0X-K2SF-00000-00VIC:Victoria to brace for harsher fire season2017-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Victoria to brace for harsher fire seasonMELBOURNE Sept 5

  Victorians need to brace themselves for a potentially harsher and earlier fire season than normal, authorities warn.
   After one of Australia's warmest and driest winters on record, large parts of the eastern states and South Australia have been marked "red" in the 2017 Southern Australia Seasonal Bushfire Outlook.


   Victoria's Emergency Management Commissioner Craig Lapsley says fire services have already started their pre-season briefings.
   The CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria have also brought forward prevention strategies, including burn-offs.
   ?The early forecast shows there is underlying dryness in some areas of the state, particularly across central parts of Victoria and across the east," he said.
   ?While there is a lot of surface water, which means there will be grass growth and a healthy supply of water for crop growing, ground moisture has the potential to dry out quickly under dry and warm conditions.
   ?The level of risk in the October to December period will still depend on how much spring rain there is in September.?
   He implored residents to start their own fire prevention works.

urn:contentItem:5N1F-X6H1-JD3N-53HH-00000-00Tyres pose safety risk2017-03-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Tyres pose safety riskLaura Armitage

TYRES illegally dumped in the Yarra State Forest could contaminate firefighting water, the State Government has warned.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has reported about 70 tyres were dumped at the state park's Brahams Rd, Warburton East entrance.

Senior forest management officer Monica Mains said the tyres were also a fire hazard.

"Tyres contain toxic chemicals that eventually leach into the environment," she said. "Recently 70 tyres were dumped in one of our firefighting water points, where we draw water from in fires.

"This contamination could have made the water unusable during fire response." Ms Mains said since the start of the year there had been about 10 cases of rubbish dumped in the forest.

"In excess of 140 tyres have been dumped on one road in the past month," she said.She said anyone with information should report it to Crime Stoppers at 1800 333 000 or phone 5965 9901.

urn:contentItem:5KC0-DTK1-JD3N-544B-00000-00PUTTING OUT FIRES2016-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 16PUTTING OUT FIRESJEN KELLY

CHARCOAL-fuelled gas producers used on cars for World War II petrol rationing had an unfortunate habit of leading to forest fires.

Ron from Elwood grew up in Macedon and remembers drivers from the city often needed to refuel on the side of the Calder Highway in the middle of the Black Forest.

"Quite often, they left a pile of smouldering embers on the side of the highway - a sure way of starting a forest fire!" Ron said.

"My mate and I had a special billycart capable of carrying two old kerosene cans filled with water."We would pull the cart along the side of the highway and douse these potential fire risks."

urn:contentItem:5M3X-2GJ1-JD34-V45H-00000-00Wind fans flames across empty highway2016-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Wind fans flames across empty highwayIAN KIRKWOOD

WITH northbound traffic stopped at the Italia Road turnoff about 10 kilometres north of Raymond Terrace, the Pacific Highway on the way into Karuah was eerily quiet on Sunday afternoon. A surprising number of houses are dotted through the bush along the way, and Rural Fire Service and National Parks and Wildlife Services were dug in at those under threat from the fire.

As the westerly wind stiffened through the day, the Lone Pine Fire, as it has been labelled, jumped the highway in various places, burning across the divided median strip and pushing east towards Swan Bay. By dusk the fire ran from Balickera to the Karuah State Forest. Fire crews said the mild conditions meant things were not as bad as they might have been.

urn:contentItem:5MW1-93K1-F0J6-J4RH-00000-00Night vision to assist fighting bushfires2017-02-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNight vision to assist fighting bushfiresCaleb Cluff

A recommendation from the 2009 Bushfires Royal Commission was put into practice over Ballarat last week as night vision goggles were used to hunt for any fires ignited by lightning strikes.

An Emergency Victoria two-person pilot and crew used a Firebird 302 helicopter customised for night vision purposes for a two-hour reconnaissance mission over the Dandenong Ranges, Healesville, Mount Macedon, Wombat State Forest, south of Ballarat into the Brisbane Ranges and Plenty Gorge.

No fires were detected, but Forest Fire Management Victoria senior aviation officer Bryan Rees said the intent was to continue to build on existing operations while maintaining specialist skills.

"This is exactly the same as reconnaissance day operations that we do all the time - but just at night.

"There are the same challenges with day operations - for example, too much cloud or smoke are still limitations at night."

Operators of night vision goggles are specially trained and accredited personnel.

urn:contentItem:5MW1-93N1-F0J6-J11B-00000-00Night vision to assist fighting bushfires2017-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNight vision to assist fighting bushfiresCaleb Cluff

A recommendation from the 2009 Bushfires Royal Commission was put into practice over Victoria last week as night vision goggles were used to hunt for any fires ignited by lightning strikes.

An Emergency Victoria two-person pilot and crew used a Firebird 302 helicopter customised for night vision purposes for a two-hour reconnaissance mission over the Dandenong Ranges, Healesville, Mount Macedon, Wombat State Forest, south of Ballarat into the Brisbane Ranges and Plenty Gorge.

No fires were detected, but Forest Fire Management Victoria senior aviation officer Bryan Rees said the intent was to continue to build on existing operations while maintaining specialist skills.

"This is exactly the same as reconnaissance day operations that we do all the time - but just at night.

"There are the same challenges with day operations - for example, too much cloud or smoke are still limitations at night."

Operators of night vision goggles are specially trained and accredited personnel.

urn:contentItem:5NH4-YR31-F0J6-J2DD-00000-00Lending a helping hand to others2017-05-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisLending a helping hand to others

Local woman Melissa Kidd joined Bendoc Brigade in 2015 as the Brigade secretary and says the brigade is really well connected with the community, seeing as most of the community is in the brigade.

Mel said her brigade is very inviting, and it's important to be a part of the small town network.

"I like the connections I have made being a volunteer in the brigade. As the Brigade secretary I am often liaising with CFA members in Bairnsdale, Victoria."

"I work for Department of Environment Land Water and Planning in Forest Fire Management and when there is a fire on I undertake my fire role as timekeeper, radio, logistics, and resourcing. This training has been very beneficial to my CFA role."

"We need more members, like many other brigades locally."

There is a role for everyone, whether it is on the fire ground, behind the scenes in your local fire station or assisting on the ground with logistics, resourcing and communications. Call 1800 232 636 for information.

urn:contentItem:5MPR-SN81-F0J6-J511-00000-00Terrain hampers control efforts2017-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisTerrain hampers control effortsJeremy Venosta

FOREST Fire Management Victoria crews worked for two days to contain a fire in rocky terrain at the Mount Cole State Park near Ararat on Sunday and Monday.

The fire burned eight hectares of bush along the Warrak-Branding Yard Track, while firefighters battled to create containment lines in tough conditions.

Incident controller John Rofe said the fire was likely sparked by a lightning storm late last week. Seventy firefighters from the fire management crews and Country Fire Authority responded to the blaze on Sunday.

Another 40 firefighters continued work to contain the fire on Monday.

Vic Emergency advised there was no threat to the Ben Nevis, Elmhurst, Eversley, Warrak, Buangor and Mount Cole communities on Sunday, but residents should continue to monitor the situation.

Ararat Fire Brigade members also completed a burn-off of scrub on the Western Highway between Green Hill Lake Road and Warrayatkin Road on Sunday.

urn:contentItem:5MN2-0R11-JD34-V4XD-00000-00Campers advised to cease polluting2017-01-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisCampers advised to cease pollutingAnthony Piovesan

Visitors using free campgrounds in Grampians regional State Forests have been warned to clean up after themselves and take their rubbish home.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Regional Manager Peter Kambouris said authorised officers were noticing an increasing number of breaches of the law.

"Along with illegal campfires, the dumping of rubbish, damage to forest roads and vandalism is occurring," he said.

"What concerns us are those people not respecting the needs and expectations of other visitors as well as our fire crews.

"We have already experienced incidents this summer of campfires being left unattended and this week, bags of rubbish were left behind at vacant campsites.

"Knowing the rules for campfire safety, proper disposal of rubbish, and treating the landscape with respect is required."

Mr Kambouris said campers should use some common sense and set a good example. "People are urged to report illegal activities observed in state forests on 136 186," he said.

urn:contentItem:5MN2-5S41-F0JP-W1FT-00000-00Burn-off concern2017-01-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Burn-off concern

MOUNT Macedon group officer Ian Hay last week expressed frustration at the level of communication about a small burn-off atop the mountain last Wednesday.

He said he only found out about the Forest Fire Management Victoria burn-off from a member of the public on Tuesday but maintained "we need to be in the loop when things like this are planned".

However, the Mt Macedon CFA captain Jim Darby said his brigade knew about the burn-off and was invited to participate.

The 100sq m burn-off of a heap on the Clyde Track started at 10.30am and finished about noon, according to FFMV.FFMV Midlands district manager Jasmine Filmer said telephone contact was made with the CFA District 2 duty officer on Monday to advise of its intention to proceed with the burn, along with a pager message to the Macedon and Kyneton brigades.

urn:contentItem:5MKS-63G1-F0J6-J2J4-00000-00Minority of campers messing it up for everyone2017-01-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisMinority of campers messing it up for everyone

Fire authorities have been disappointed by the behaviour of some holiday-makers in the nearby East Gippsland region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria compliance staff have been patrolling park and forest campsites. Overall, they say they have been pleased with people's behaviour.

"[However,] It's a shame that a minority often spoil it for others and that our officers have seen some disappointing behaviour, found a number of unattended campfires and an appalling amount of rubbish dumped at popular campsites," Gippsland's Assistant Chief Fire Officer Chris Stephenson said.

"We find it hard to believe that this sort of irresponsible behaviour continues year after year, putting the community and the environment at risk," Mr Stephenson said.

"Our authorised officers try to get to as many sites as possible, but Gippsland has over three million hectares of public land."

Report suspicious and illegal behaviour in parks and forests to DELWP on 136 186.

urn:contentItem:5P22-7HK1-F0JP-W0HS-00000-00Feral pigs: hunters in sights2017-07-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Feral pigs: hunters in sightsBy KATE DOWLER

HUNTERS have been accused of illegally releasing feral pigs in southwest Victoria.

Numbers of the destructive and disease-carrying pests are rising on public land and farms.

Forest Fire Management Victoria officer James Downie said while isolated populations of feral pigs had been present for some time, their numbers were growing.

"We believe the origin of these newly confirmed populations is most likely through importation and illegal release," Mr Downie said.

"We are seeing evidence of feral pigs that have had their ears cut off consistent with the theory that some pigs were released with the intent of breeding up to allow for increased hunting opportunities." Invasive Species Council chief executive Andrew Cox said hunters had been known to cut ears off female pigs so hunting dogs could not catch them.

Sporting Shooters' Association of Australia Victoria hunting development manager David Laird said "claims hunters have released pigs have been bandied about for years"."We'd certainly be concerned if it was (happening) - it would be illegal. It is not something we support."

urn:contentItem:5MJP-9FH1-F0J6-J3SN-00000-00Reckless campers threaten forests2017-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Reckless campers threaten forests

FOREST authorities have issued a stern warning to campers and holiday makers after reckless campers have left several unattended campfires the past few days in parks and reserves across the Grampians.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Grampians forest and fire operations manager Peter Kambouris region said it was increasing the risk of bushfires.

Forecasts indicate high fire danger ratings during the coming days and weeks. Mr Kambouris reminded campers to make sure they were informed before heading into the bush and practised good campfire safety.

"One of the biggest bushfire risks on public land during summer remains unattended camp fires that have not been extinguished correctly. While most campers do the right thing, unfortunately we continue to find a minority of campers who do not," Mr Kambouris said.

Campfires should be cool to touch and extinguished with water not soil.

Fire danger ratings: cfa.vic.gov.au. Parks information: parks.vic.gov.au

urn:contentItem:5MFX-P3P1-F0J6-J10T-00000-00Firies team up to give warning2016-12-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Firies team up to give warningChris Young

FIREFIGHTERS from both sides of the Border have joined forces to urge common sense across the Christmas period.

NSW Fire and Rescue, the NSW Rural Fire Service, Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA teamed up on Friday to issue a warning about the upcoming fire season.

"Our message is that people need to know the rules about total fire bans," FFMV's David Ross said.

"Campfires shouldn't be lit on days of total fire ban, should always be extinguished with water and soil and should be cold to the touch before you leave."

Barbecues were also a concern for NSW Fire and Rescue Inspector Stewart Alexander.

"We know you might use your barbecues for Christmas breakfast, lunch and dinner, but please be diligent and check them first," he said.

"Too many fires start as a result of loose connections or damaged gas cylinders.

"Give your barbecue a once over."

urn:contentItem:5M4Y-XTW1-F0J6-J1F5-00000-00NPWS working to contain lightning-strike fire in Bindarri National Parkâ€‹2016-11-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:01:01ZLexisNexisNPWS working to contain lightning-strike fire in Bindarri National Parkâ€‹Alice Burnet

The National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) is working with the Rural Fire Service (RFS) and Forestry Corporation to establish containment strategies for a bushfire in Bindarri National Park north of Bellingen.

NPWS area manager Glenn Storrie said the fire was started by lightning on Tuesday evening (8 November).

"The fire is burning in very steep terrain making direct access to the fire very difficult," Mr Storrie said.

"There is a lot of smoke being generated however, the fire is slow moving and there is no immediate risk to property," he said.

"NPWS, RFS and State Forest fire crews are working to preparing a containment strategy to prevent this fire spreading from the Park.

"The fire is being monitored including by helicopter," Mr Storrie said.
